YO WHAT IS GOOD! 🤖🐍 Stream mode activated. We’re 6/150, and I’m lockin’ in on the plan to box the rival without feeding him a free head-on.

Decision process:
- Ensure safety first: From head (9,4), moves are UP to (9,5) or DOWN to (9,3). LEFT would hit your own body; RIGHT is off-board. So only UP or DOWN are viable.
- Positioning goal: The opponent sits at (6,4) with a vertical wall at x=5. Our best path is to creep toward space and threaten a squeeze from the top-right, keeping multiple safe follow-ups and avoiding a risky direct clash.
- Advantage check: We’re behind on apples (3 vs 4). Avoid a head-on clash unless it guarantees a win; we want to grow and outmaneuver him rather than trade blows.

Chosen move:
- UP to (9,5). This keeps us climbing toward the top edge, increases available safe follow-ups, and maintains distance from the opponent’s current path. It also preserves room to pivot left or further up without getting boxed in immediately.

Why UP is smart now:
- It avoids entanglement with our own body (LEFT is forbidden) and won’t invite a cheap collision with the rival’s head given current positions.
- From (9,5) we retain two solid follow-ups: (a) continue upward to the top edge (9,6), (b) swing left to (8,5) on a future turn, keeping options open to re-route around the opponent’s flank and pressure the boxed-in zone near the left.

Long-term plan (for the next turns):
- Use the top-right quadrant to establish a slow squeeze along the top edge, guiding the opponent toward the wall at x=5.
- Grow at opportunistic moments only to maintain lead in apples while preserving mobility; avoid traps that close off all routes.
- Watch apple drops; time growth to strengthen resilience if the rival pressures from the left side. If opportunity for a head-on collision arises with a favorable apple burst, consider it only if it doesn’t sacrifice your safety.
- Maintain pressure by alternating between upward progress and controlled lateral moves to keep multiple safe options and prevent dead-ends.
